contextId.information: Paul wishes to emphasize the truth that Christ is not divided but one. "It is not possible to divide Christ in the way you are doing!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Is Christ divided?

contextId.information: Paul wishes to emphasize that it was Christ, not Paul or Apollos, who was crucified. This can also be translated in active form. AT: "It certainly was not put Paul whom they put to death on the cross for your salvation!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Was Paul crucified for you?

contextId.information: Paul uses this question to emphasize that no one knows the mind of the Lord. AT: "No one can know the mind of the Lord, so no one can teach him anything he does not already know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For who can know the mind of the Lord, that he can instruct him?

contextId.information: Paul is rebuking the Corinthians. AT: "You act as though you do not know that you are God's temple and the Spirit of God lives in you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that you are God's temple and that the Spirit of God lives in you?

contextId.information: Paul is rebuking the Corinthians who think they are better than those who heard the gospel from someone else. AT: "You are not superior to other men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For who sees any difference between you and others?

contextId.information: Paul was rebuking them for boasting in what they received. AT: "You do not have the right to boast" or "Do not boast at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why do you boast as if you had not done so?

contextId.information: Paul was making a last appeal to the Corinthians, as he has been rebuking them for the errors they had made. AT: "Tell me what you want to happen now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What do you want?

contextId.information: Paul is offering the Corinthians two opposing attitudes he could use when approaching them. AT: "If you want, I can come to punish you, or I can come to show you how much I love you by being gentle with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Shall I come to you with a rod or with love and in a spirit of gentleness

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is used to scold the Corinthians. AT: "You should mourn over this instead!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should you not mourn instead?

contextId.information: Paul is emphasizing that he is not the one to judge people outside the church. This can also be stated in active form. AT: "I am not the one who should judge people who do not belong to the church" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how am I involved with judging those who are outside the church?

contextId.information: Paul is emphasizing that Christians must resolve disagreements among themselves. AT: "he should not dare to go ... believers!" or "he should be fear God and not go ... believers!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: does he dare to go ... believers?

contextId.information: Paul is shaming the Corinthians for acting like they do not know. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that the believers will judge the world?

contextId.information: Paul is surprised that they do not seem to know. "You know that we will judge the angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that we will judge the angels?

contextId.information: "Because we know we will judge the angels, we can also be sure that God will enable us to judge matters in this life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How much more, then, can we judge matters of this life?

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a rhetorical question (UDB) or 2) this is a statement, "When in the past you have settled matters that are important in this life, you have not handed off disputes between Christians to be settled by unbelievers" or 3) this is a command, "When you settle matters that are important in this life, it is even to those who have no standing in the church that you should hand off disputes to be settled!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If then you have to make judgments that pertain to daily life, why do you lay such cases as these before those who have no standing in the church?

contextId.information: "you should not lay such cases" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why do you lay such cases

contextId.information: Paul is rebuking the Corinthians for how they are handling these cases. Possible meanings are that 1) "you should stop giving such cases to people who are outside the church" or 2) "you could give such cases even to members of the church who are not well regarded by other believers." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: those who have no standing in the church

contextId.information: Paul is shaming the Corinthians. AT: "You should be ashamed that you cannot find a wise believer to settle arguments between believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is there no one among you wise enough to settle a dispute between brothers?

contextId.information: Paul continues to shame the Corinthians. AT: "It would be better to let others wrong you and cheat you than to take them to court." (See; [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why not rather suffer the wrong? Why not rather allow yourselves to be cheated?

contextId.information: Paul emphasizes that they should already know this truth. AT: "You already know that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that

contextId.information: Paul is using himself as an example to teach them. AT: "I am part of Christ. I will not take myself away from Christ and join myself to a prostitute!" or "We are parts of Christ's body. We should not take ourselves away from Christ and join ourselves to prostitutes!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Shall I then take away the members of Christ and join them to a prostitute?

contextId.information: Paul begins to teach the Corinthians by emphasizing a truth that they already know. "I want to remind you that ... her." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that ... her?

contextId.information: Paul is continuing to teach the Corinthians by emphasizing what they already know. AT: "I want to remind you ... God and that you are not your own." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know ... God? ... that you are not your own?

contextId.information: This can be stated directly. AT: "you cannot know if you will save your unbelieving husband" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how do you know, woman, whether you will save your husband?

contextId.information: Paul was addressing the circumcised ones (the Jews). AT: "To the circumcised ones, when God called you to believe, you had already been circumcised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Was anyone circumcised when he was called to believe

contextId.information: Paul addresses men who are not married. AT: "If you are not now married, do not seek" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you free of a wife? Do not seek

contextId.information: Paul uses this rhetorical question to remind the Corinthians of the rights he has. AT: "I am a free person." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Am I not free?

contextId.information: Paul uses this rhetorical question to remind the Corinthians of who he is. AT: "I have seen Jesus our Lord." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have I not seen Jesus our Lord?

contextId.information: Paul uses this rhetorical question to remind the Corinthians of their relationship to him. AT: "You believe in Christ because I have worked the way the Lord wants me to." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you not my workmanship in the Lord?

contextId.information: Paul uses a question to emphasize that he knows the Corinthians agree with what he is saying. AT: "We have the absolute right to receive food and drink from the churches." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do we not have the right to eat and drink?

contextId.information: Paul uses a question to emphasize that he knows the Corinthians agree with what he is saying. AT: "If we have believing wives, we have a right to take them with us just as the other apostles take them, and the brothers of the Lord, and Cephas." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do we not have the right to take along with us a wife who is a believer, as do the rest of the apostles, and the brothers of the Lord, and Cephas?

contextId.information: Paul uses a question to emphasize that he knows the Corinthians agree with what he is saying. AT: "We all know that no soldier has to buy his own supplies." or "We all know that every soldier receives his supplies from the government." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).
contextId.quote: Who serves as a soldier at his own expense?

contextId.information: Paul uses a question to emphasize that he knows the Corinthians agree with what he is saying. AT: "We all know that those who tend flocks get their drink from the flocks." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Or who tends a flock and does not drink milk from it?

contextId.information: Paul is shaming the Corinthians. AT: "You act as if you do not know that this is what is written in the law." (See; [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Does not the law also say this?

contextId.information: Paul asks a question so that the Corinthians will think of what he is saying without him having to say it. AT: "You should know without me telling you that it is not the oxen that God cares most about." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it really the oxen that God cares about?

contextId.information: Paul asks a question so that the Corinthians will think of what he is saying without him having to say it. AT: "you should know without me telling you that  it is not too much for us to receive material support from you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: is it too much for us to reap material things from you?

contextId.information: Paul is reminding the Corinthians of what they know so he can add new information. AT: "I want to remind you that those who serve in the temple get their food from the temple." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that those who serve in the temple get their food from the temple?

contextId.information: Paul is reminding the Corinthians of what they know so he can add new information. "Let me remind you that although all runners run the race, only one runner receives the prize." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run the race, but that only one receives the prize?

contextId.information: Paul is reminding the Corinthians of what they already know, that the cup of wine that we share represents us sharing in the blood of Christ. AT: "we share in the blood of Christ." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: is it not a sharing in the blood of Christ?

contextId.information: Paul is reminding the Corinthians of what they already know so that he can give them new information. AT: "those who eat the sacrifices share in the activities and the blessings of the altar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: are not those who eat the sacrifices participants in the altar?

contextId.information: Paul wants the Corinthians to answer the question in their minds so he does not have to tell them. AT: "You know that I am not saying that an idol is something real." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: That an idol is anything?

contextId.information: The speaker wants the hearer to answer the question in his mind. AT: "You should know without me telling you that no one should be able to say I am doing wrong just because that person has ideas about right and wrong that are different from mine. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why should my freedom be judged by another's conscience?

contextId.information: Paul expects the Corinthians to agree with him. AT: "Nature itself even teaches you ... for him." He is speaking of the way people in society normally act as if it were a person who teaches. AT: "You know just from looking at the way people normally act ... for him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Does not even nature itself teach you ... for him?

contextId.information: This can be made a statement. AT: "you could not hear anything ... you could not smell anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: where would the sense of hearing be? ... where would the sense of smell be?

contextId.information: This can be made a statement. AT: "there would be no body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: where would the body be?

contextId.information: Paul is reminding his readers of what they already know. AT: "Only some of them are apostles. Only some of them are prophets. Only some of them are teachers. Only some of them do powerful deeds." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are all of them apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all do powerful deeds?

contextId.information: This can be a statement. AT: "I will not benefit you" or "I will not have done anything that helps you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how will I benefit you

contextId.information: Paul wants the Corinthians to answer this themselves. AT: "no one will know what tune the flute or harp is playing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how will anyone know what tune the flute or harp is playing?

contextId.information: Paul wants the Corinthians to answer this themselves. AT:  "no one would know when it is time to prepare for battle." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how will anyone know when it is time to prepare for battle?

contextId.information: Paul is introducing his conclusion. AT: "This is what I will do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What am I to do?

contextId.information: Paul emphasizes that the Corinthians are not the only ones who understand what God wants Christians to do. AT: "The word of God did not come from you in Corinth; you are not the only people who understand God's will." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did the word of God come from you? Are you the only ones it has reached?

contextId.information: Paul is using this question to begin a new topic. AT: "you should not be saying that there is no resurrection of the dead!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how can some of you say there is no resurrection of the dead?

contextId.information: Paul wants the Corinthians to understand without him having to tell them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Otherwise it would be useless for Christians to receive baptism for the dead." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Or else what will those do who are baptized for the dead?

contextId.information: Paul wants the Corinthians to understand without him having to tell them. This can be a statement. AT:"I gained nothing ... by fighting with beasts at Ephesus ... not raised." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What do I gain ... if I fought with beasts at Ephesus ... not raised?
